text: Crazy management, after drop off, by right we can drive away easily by turning left. But they want us to drive one big round thru the narrow and dangerous route, really nonsense!

Lot of children "education institutions" n a residential block coming up... First level, have Korean BBQ/ fishop (fresh seafood restaurant) / burger king/ other cafes n art shop n on second level, bodhi meditation/ cold storage.. . Building (link @ 869) just next to king Albert MRT station...

Link@896 seems to be undergoing some major renovations at the moment, which is noticeable throughout the building. However, the reason I still come here regularly is that my son attends Wang Learning Centre, which is conveniently located within the complex. Despite the ongoing renovations, I appreciate the ample parking provided. The long grace period for parking is a huge plus, as it gives us plenty of time to fetch our kids without having to rush or worry about parking fees.

Though the renovations are ongoing, I look forward to seeing the improvements once they are complete, as it could potentially elevate the overall experience at Link@896. For now, the convenience of parking and accessibility for our family makes it a frequent stop for us.

Another good location for kids enrichment or learning centres to go to . A small handful of restaurants and cafe plus Cold Storage for your daily needs. Walking distance from MRT (Down Town Line, DT6) . Parents  do check this place out for yours and childâ€™s convenience. Cheerrrss!!!

** For those driving and looking for a place to park, take note of the weird traffic flow or direction upon entering via the gantry.

A centre with many enrichment/educational centres but bad traffic management for parents waiting to drop and pick up their kids. Cars are often stuck at the entrance/exit due to poor traffic flow within the building compound. I do not understand why the building management has to block off one lane to forbid parents from temporary parking along the lane. They need to look into this issue. Deploying private traffic wardens and cones are not effective solutions.
